SENT.plain: Eleven patients with large cerebellar infarctions were admitted recently to our service
Eight of them showed evidence of hydrocephalus on the CT scan examination
Five were treated with controlled external ventricular drainage and six were managed conservatively
One death, most likely due to progressive brainstem infarction, occurred
The outcome was favorable in the other patients
It is suggested that prompt treatment of the acute obstructive hydrocephalus may obviate the need for posterior fossa decompression in patients with massive cerebellar infarction
